Introduction

Transverse myelitis (TM) is an inflammatory disorder of the spinal cord characterized by rapid onset of neurologic symptoms.

Pathophysiology



TM is an immune-mediated disorder characterized by infiltration of inflammatory cells into a segment of the spinal cord.  This leads to neuron and oligodendrocyte cell death and demyelination, which causes neurologic impairment in a characteristic pattern.

Epidemiology and risk factors



Most cases of TM follow a recent infection (eg, gastroenteritis, upper respiratory infection).  The condition is also associated with various autoimmune disorders, including multiple sclerosis, neuromyelitis optica, and systemic diseases (eg, systemic lupus erythematosus).  TM has a bimodal peak, with most cases occurring in the teens and 30s.

Clinical presentation



Patients with TM typically have acute-onset, rapidly progressive myelopathy that localizes to ≥1 contiguous spinal cord segments (usually in the thoracic cord).  This is usually characterized by the following:



  • Motor weakness:  usually accompanied by upper motor neuron signs (eg, hyperreflexia, upgoing plantar reflex) due to involvement of the long tracts.  Less commonly, patients may have lower motor neuron signs (eg, flaccid paralysis) due to involvement of the gray matter of the spinal cord.
  • Sensory dysfunction:  affects all somatosensory systems (eg, touch, pain/temperature, vibration/proprioception) with a distinct sensory level (ie, lowest spinal cord level with intact sensation).
  • Autonomic dysfunction:  often includes bowel/bladder incontinence or retention.


Symptoms typically develop over the course of hours to days.  The head is usually not affected and patients have normal levels of consciousness.

Diagnosis



TM is diagnosed with a combination of clinical findings and confirmatory imaging studies.  Patients with concern for TM usually have an urgent spine MRI with and without contrast to rule out lesions causing cord compression that can mimic TM.  MRI of the spine shows a contrast-enhancing lesion and T2 hyperintensity due to an increase in water content from inflammatory infiltrate in the spinal cord (

image 1
).  The lesion occurs over ≥1 contiguous spinal cord segments.  Though it is not necessary for diagnosis, many patients also have lumbar puncture for cerebrospinal fluid analysis; this can show supportive evidence of inflammation with a mild pleocytosis and elevated IgG index.  Brain MRI with and without contrast is also usually done to evaluate for lesions suggestive of multiple sclerosis.

Differential diagnosis



  • Guillain-Barré syndrome:  can present with rapidly progressive, ascending weakness; however, upper motor neuron signs (eg, hyperreflexia, upgoing Babinski) and a distinct sensory level would not be present.
  • Infarction of the anterior spinal artery:  can result in motor weakness and loss of pain and temperature sensation below the level of the infarction.  However, vibration and proprioception would be spared, which is unusual in TM as it affects all sensory systems.
  • Spinal epidural abscess:  can present with progressive myelopathy due to cord compression from an expanding infection in the spinal column.  Associated neurologic deficits may have significant overlap with TM; however, patients classically have localized back pain and fever.
  • Vitamin B12 deficiency:  can cause degeneration of the dorsal and lateral spinal tracts (ie, subacute combined degeneration), resulting in sensory ataxia with progressive spastic paraparesis and incontinence.  However, it does not present acutely and does not cause a distinct sensory level.

Management



Because TM is an immune-mediated disorder, high-dose intravenous glucocorticoids for 3-5 days are typically given for first-line management.  In addition, plasmapheresis is recommended for patients who have significant motor symptoms or do not respond to glucocorticoids.

Prognosis



The outcome of TM varies; recovery can take months to years.  Some patients recover with minimal or no residual effects, while others have permanent deficits.

Summary



Transverse myelitis is a neurological condition characterized by a segmental inflammation of the spinal cord.  It presents with rapid-onset motor, sensory, and autonomic dysfunction.  Patients often have a distinct sensory level.  The diagnosis is made with clinical evaluation and supportive MRI findings.  Management involves acute immunomodulatory treatments such as steroids or plasmapheresis.
